[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker provide a malicious path containing '../' sequences that escapes the intended package directory when passed to reroot_path(), potentially accessing or executing prover verification on sensitive system files outside the package boundary? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Symlink Attack] Can an attacker create symbolic links in the package path that cause reroot_path() to resolve to unintended directories, allowing verification of malicious Move code or exfiltration of source code through prover error messages? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Race Condition] When reroot_path() calls std::env::set_current_dir(), can a concurrent thread or process exploit the TOCTOU (time-of-check-time-of-use) window between path validation and directory change to swap the target directory, causing the prover to run on malicious code? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Denial of Service] Can an attacker provide a deeply nested or circular directory path that causes reroot_path() to consume excessive resources during canonicalization, leading to CPU exhaustion or stack overflow in the path resolution logic? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Directory Persistence] Since reroot_path() permanently changes the current working directory via set_current_dir(), can this side effect cause security issues in multi-threaded environments where other threads expect a specific working directory, potentially leading to unintended file operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Configuration Injection] When loading Prover.toml at line 61-64, can an attacker craft a malicious Prover.toml file with injected prover options that override security-critical settings, such as disabling verification checks or enabling unsafe features? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Path Traversal in Config] Can an attacker manipulate the Prover.toml path construction at line 61 by providing a rerooted_path containing special characters or path traversal sequences that cause the config file to be loaded from an unintended location? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Symlink Confusion] If Prover.toml is a symbolic link to a malicious configuration file outside the package directory, will the exists() check at line 62 follow the symlink and load untrusted configuration, bypassing intended security boundaries? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Config Override Attack] Since Prover.toml options are added before user-provided opts at line 65, can an attacker place a malicious Prover.toml in the package that sets dangerous defaults which users may not realize are being applied, leading to incomplete verification? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Unicode Normalization] Can an attacker use Unicode normalization vulnerabilities in the Prover.toml path construction to create files with visually similar but different names, causing the wrong configuration file to be loaded? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Option Injection] Can an attacker craft malicious ProverOptions::Options containing specially formatted strings that override critical security settings when passed to the prover, such as '--unsafe-mode' or options that disable verification checks? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-cli/src/base/prove.rs] [Function: Prove::execute()] [Format String Attack] Can the format!() macro at line 63 be exploited if prover_toml.to_string_lossy() contains format string specifiers, leading to information disclosure or unexpected behavior in the configuration string?
